"In other words, (WTC 1 and WTC 2, respectively) the falling upper mass onto the supporting structure below of 98 & 82 floors, which were below and not on fire or damaged (which were designed to support only the static weight of the floors above and not any dynamic effects (a.k.a. dynamic weight), (the structure below) was unable to even slow (a.k.a. decelerate) the falling mass."

But objects in Free Fall have no weight, therefore no dynamic weight or static weight. He’s wrong. The earth doesn’t spin because it was formed from spinning dust. While the dust the earth formed from may be the reason that the earth’s axis drifts a degree every few thousand years, it is not the reason for the earth’s daily 360 degree rotation. The rotation of the earth was caused when a planet roughly the size of mars collided with the earth. The earth was sent spinning, and the residual debris from the collision was pulled together by gravity to form the moon.

Is there a rule that dictates the settling dust must, on average, orbit in a particular direction? I imagine if every orbit is equally likely, then the net momentum of all that dust would be zero.

Pretty sure most if not all planets spin.
Their angular momentum is defined during the condensing stage of gas clouds.

To my understanding,
Since the conservation of momentum is acting on the particles (to my understanding, roughly, no non-neglible outside force is effecting this specific gas cloud during collision).
So the sum of their angular momentum is kept from the begining.

So their spin is actually the result of many particles hitting each other, summing up their velocity vectors, and the "vertical" component of their velocity being canceled out by this hitting, until they reach a somewhat stable and general angular velocity in the horizontal component.

Note as he said, this is not necessarily a matter of force.
Rather it is a matter of momentum.

The question of what started it spinning is a bit misguided in that zero rotation (angular momentum) is  not some default state. It seems that way because we see few things around us spinning unless we set them in motion. That's because there are torques such as friction opposing rotation. In the case of the earth, the opposing torque is very small compared to the inertia, so the rate of slowing is very small. This is mainly due to gravitational interaction with the moon, and it tells you how huge the inertia is that this effect is so small. Yes, there would be some specific forces resulting in a net torque that would set the forming earth into rotation, but it would have been a miracle if there weren't.

Actually, gravity IS the MAIN cause of the Earth's spinning - without gravity, the Earth would not even exist, so although inertia is also important, it is thanks to GRAVITY that we can talk about all this in the first place. Gravity > inertia. :-D When the Earth formed, matter moving through space accumulated in one place due to gravity. Without gravity, the matter would just keep moving in a straight line thanks to inertia until it would randomly impact another piece of matter or get destroyed somehow. This would gradually lead to a universe full of tiny bits of ~evenly distributed matter. But gravity made the bits of matter move in curves, leading to the rotation of the accretion disk and the resulting Earth. The bottom line is that gravity CAUSES the rotation (without gravity, it would be just linear motion), inertia just KEEPS IT GOING. Therefore, if you want INERTIA as the answer, you have to ask: "WHAT MAKES THE EARTH KEEP SPINNING?" :-)

Actually gravity does play a part. Gravity is the force that's perpendicular to the velocity of molecules traveling in a specific direction. Without gravity, molecules will continue to stay in motion unless a force acts upon it to change it's velocity (either speed or direction). Since gravity (aka gravitational force) is a force acting on upon these molecules (by changing direction) thus is perpendicular to the direction of the velocity of the molecules, we have rotational inertia. Sooooo...gravity is the reason it spins. The direction of the spin has to do with the spinning dust cloud theory.

Not quite right.  Inertia is the tendency of an object at rest to stay at rest or an object moving in a straight line to continue moving in a straight line at the same velocity.  This is also known as the conservation of momentum which is mass times velocity.  But the globe spins because of the conservation of angular momentum, which is angular rotational velocity times the moment of inertia.  Related, but not exactly the same.

The law of inertia states that any object with mass will keep moving if no other force acts upon it. This means its velocity remains constant.
However in order to change direction it needs a force to do so. A rotating object does not have velocity, it has acceleration - it is constantly changing direction and does not move in a straight line. Velocity only applies to an object moving in a straight line.
Therefore the law of inertia does not apply to a spinning object. A force is required to keep an object spinning.
So let's ask the question again because this video has not answered it.

What is the force that keeps the Earth spinning?

The earth we're standing on spins because when it formed the dust and rocks that made it up probably sent each other into a spin as they rushed toward each other at different angles, and it just never stopped spinning because there's no force to resist the spin in space. Good thing too, or we wouldn't get the gyroscope effect that keeps us tilted at an angle to the sun and allows for us to have seasons.
However the globe being held up by a film of water that you're standing right next to is probably spinning for the same reason that water spins when it runs down a drain: The coreolis effect. One of two things is true:
One end of that globe is moving slightly faster than the other, so it outruns it, and since the center is held in a fixed location, the globe spins. This would produce a counter clockwise rotation because the globe is in the Northern hemisphere.
Or
The globe is floating in space, held up by the water, and as the earth rotates, inertia keeps the globe from spinning with it. This would produce a clockwise rotation because the globe is in the Northern hemisphere.
Interesting question though: If left on its own, would the globe spin clockwise, or counter-clockwise? Either way, the axis would be tilted toward the north pole, running exactly parallel with the Earth's own axis of rotation. At the equator, this globe would naturally roll on its side.

One thing has me thinking: it is assumed that Earth formed from a large mass of debris left in the plane of the disc from which the solar system formed, when the debris kinda partitioned itself in belts which later would become planets. I have no problem with that, it seems reasonable.

But why does it spin the way it does? If we assume the so-called "future Earth debris disc" was spinning(let's say the net spin of everything it was made of) around its gravitational center, then condensed and turned into round, rotating Earth, it would have to rotate the way Earth does now, meaning counter-clockwise. But why would it be doing so?

As the planets orbit around the Sun counter-clockwise, the debris disc also had to rotate that way. The closer a circular orbit is to the Sun, the higher the angular velocity is. meaning the inner side of the disc would be orbiting the sun a little bit faster than the outer side, meaning the net spin of the future-Earth would be clockwise. The matter condensing into one lump would only increase the speed of rotation...

Ah, but why was the dust spinning in the first place? (The answer is that the net angular momentum of a huge mass of randomly-moving particles around the center of mass is unlikely to be exactly zero, i.e. a mass of randomly-moving particles has a nonzero (albeit diffused) net angular momentum about its center of mass. Tidal forces and cataclysmic meteor impacts notwithstanding, the net angular momentum of the system will be conserved independently of its spatial distribution of mass. Consequently, as the particles coalesce under the force of gravity and assume the same motion, the conserved net angular momentum of a large, slowly-moving dust cloud transforms into a dense, relatively fast-spinning planet).

Someone asked the question of why a system would be rotating in the first place.  The answer to this is NOT gravity, but just simply the imbalance of forces.  ANY net force on a system will cause rotation of some sort.  THEN gravity will increase the rotation as it draws the system in.  If you are ONLY talking about the moon, then tidal forces slow it down, but gravity did not cause the rotation in ANY of the moons.  An imbalance of forces did.

"does somethiing then kick-in to keep it exactly at this orbital speed?" - No.  Tidal forces are why the rotational speed of all these moons you mentioned slowed down to begin with.  It is impossible for tidal forces to slow the rotation of a moon to a period any slower than that moon's orbital period around its parent.  Rotational period increases for a system as the mass draws closer to the center due to the conservation of angular momentum (like a figure skater).

Gravity didn't cause rotation directly.  The original rotation didn't need gravity to exist.  The only thing gravity was responsible for was drawing all the debris closer and closer together.  Conservation of angular momentum is why the original rotation speed (which gravity did not cause) increased.  The closer everything was together, the faster it spun.  Today, gravity is done compressing the material into what is the Earth, and the inertia of the Earth maintains the rotation.

The effect of solar wind on the Earth's orbit is so small it can pretty much be ignored. This is because the solar wind is does not carry much momentum compared to the momentum of the Earth in it's orbit. While some of the momentum from the solar wind is transferred to the Earth, it is not enough to significantly affect our orbit. A good metaphor for this is to think of a gentle breeze blowing on a large bowling ball, as opposed to air and a curve ball.

When two objects are attracted towards each other in space, it is a very slight chance that those objects will actually hit each other. There's a much higher chance that they will miss and spin around in their elliptical orbits of each other, perhaps veering ever so slightly closer each orbit until they finally collide and form a larger object. When they do this, the larger object formed by the combination is spinning in the same direction of the orbit of the two smaller objects to begin with.

As the dust and gas that form objects collapse the individual bits would form orbits around the net center of mass, with heavier bits tending to lower orbits and lighter bits higher orbits. As the particles fuse and clump into a single body the momentum from the orbits would be conserved, turning into a spinning object with the same net momentum.

A fledgling star gathers a disk of dust and gas around itself, as things coalesce, the star's gravitational orbit sets that dust and gas to spinning. Since gravity pulls inward from all directions equally, the amorphous clump, if massive enough, will eventually become a round planet. Inertia then keeps that planet spinning on its axis unless something occurs to disturb it. The Earth keeps spinning because it was born spinning.

Evidence: almost everything that we observe about planetary systems.

Conclusion: planetary systems formed from spinning dust and gas.

Alternative hypotheses: none.

Dunk: slammed.

What you are talking about is the coriolis effect. the coriolis effect is the apparent change in trajectory an object has when traveling fast enough, and over far enough distances that the rotational speed significantly varies.  For example, if you dug a hole straight down, and you dropped objects straight down that hole, they would eventually hit the edge because the farther down the hole you go, the slower the rotation of the Earth becomes.  This HAS been observed, and it happens.

The ball on the water fountain spins due to the Coriolis Effect.  If the ball were in the southern hemisphere, it would spin clockwise.  If you stopped the ball with your hand or some other form of drag, the ball would eventually start spinning again.  This is the same effect that causes tropical weather systems to spin counter-clockwise in the northern hemisphere and clockwise in the southern hemisphere.  This same effect takes place within the confines of a solar system or galactic system.

But the answer is not gravity still!  Its the initial conditions of the debris/dust which compacted to form the earth.
 The internal gravity force between the debris particles cannot change the total angular momentum (AM) of the debris system, it is conserved. The debris system had a small AM to begin with, and as it compacted by gravity the moment of inertia decreased. Hence angular velocity increased to the current spin rate of earth, to conserve the AM.

Gravity. When matter starts accumulating into a star, it spins and forms a disk. Some interesting facts:
1) If there were no gravity, Earth would not be spinning at the first place.
2) If Earth was spinning and gravity suddenly disappeared, it would stop spinning and disseminate into pieces of rocks that are moving away from each other (due to the centripetal force that existed at the time of spinning).
3) If Inertia didn't exist, Earth would start spinning, but eventually slow down and stop.

@Ace1of2Spades3 I don't think inertia can be calculated... It's just a tendency. But you can calculate how much mass something has by how much it tends to resist acceleration. Say you applied a 50 N force (F) to a ball of unknown mass (m) in the middle of space and it reaches 1 meter per second (velocity) in 1 second (time). Acceleration (a) is the change in velocity divided by the change in time. So 1/1 = 1 meter per second per second. Then use Newton's Second Law (F = m*a) and solve for m.

No, inertia is also the resistance of a spinning object to stop spinning. Put most simply, inertia says that if you want to CHANGE how something is moving, that requires energy. 

Flywheels, for example, are designed to have a high inertia. That means they are hard to get spinning, but once they are spinning, they are just as hard to slow down. 

It works both ways. If you fire a bullet, inertia is responsible for the recoil upon firing, AND the damage upon impact.
